Introduction

Javascript's window object gives you access to manipulate or control the web brower, this is called Brower Control. In this article you'll learn how to get the browers current Uniform Resourse Location (URL) and change it to what ever you want using Javascript.

Getting the Brower Current URL

To get the current URL, call the href method on the window.location object.

JAVASCRIPT
const currentURL = window.location.href
console.log(currentURL)

Note that the href method will get you the full URL. But you can get the URL in pieces by calling other methods on the window.location object.

Use the pathname method to get only the current path.

JAVASCRIPT
const currentPath = window.location.pathname
console.log(currentPath)

Use the hostname method to get only the domain or site name.

JAVASCRIPT
const domainName = window.location.hostname

If the URL includes an Anchor pointing to a section of the page, use the hash method to get it.

JAVASCRIPT
const theAnchor = window.location.hash

Setting the Brower Current URL

As metioned earlier, you can also tell the browser to navigate to a different destination or URL path.

JAVASCRIPT
window.location.href = "www.google.com/search"

The above code will navigate your brower to google's search page.

Below is a common use case for redirecting your browser to a different page on your current website.

JAVASCRIPT
var currentSite = window.location.hostname;
var destination = "http://" + currentSite + "/another-page";
window.location.href = destination;
smallbody: Learn how to get the browser's current URL and change it to whatever you want using Javascript.

Introduction

Creating a Mongo Database Cluster is the first step to working with mongodb. This article will take you through a step by step guide on how to create a free mongo database in the mongodb official website and generate a Database Connection URL.

A Database Connection URL is a string that your DBMS JDBC driver uses to connect to a database. It can contain information such as where to search for the database, the name of the database to connect to, and configuration properties.

ref: docs.oracle.com

Create a Free Mongodb Atlas Account

To use mongodb, you'll need a free MongoDB Atlas Account. Follow the following steps to do so:

  1. Head to the mongodb official website
  2. Click on "try free" to sign up
  3. Fill the form that follows to create a free Mongodb Atlas Account
  4. Verify your email account and sign in using your set email and passoword

Create a Database

Notice the "project menu" at top-left coner. Every Mongodb Database must be in a project. Mongodb creates a default project ( 'project 0' ), but you can create as many projects as you want by clicking on the project menu. We'll be using the default for now.

Now lets create your first Database:

  1. Click on "Build a Database"
  2. Choose a deployment option

    3. Any of the deployment option will work for this tutorial, but I'll recommend starting out with the free Shared option for learning and exploring MongoDB in a sandbox environment..

  3. Additional Information

    4. You can provide addition information about your Database Cluster, such as Cloud Provider & Region, Cluster Tier etc. I have left every option as default except for the Cluster Name which I've changed to Tutorial-cluster

  4. Click "Create Cluster"
  5. Security Quickstart Options

    6. To access data stored in Atlas, you'll need to create users and set up network security controls.

    Choose Username and Password as your authentication method and create a user

    Choose My Local Environment as your network access method and click "Add My Current IP Address" to give connection access to your current device

    Click "finish and close"

Generate a Connection URL

Now our Database is created, we can now generate a Connection URL to connect to our Database

  1. Start by clicking on the "connection" button shown in the above image
  2. Next, choose a connection method that suit your use case ( for this tutorial we'll use 'connect your application' )
  3. Choose the driver and version you're working with and your connection string will be generated for you

Don't forget to replace the <password> param with your Mongodb Atlas Account password

Introduction

Mongodb is classified as a JSON-like, document oriented database programme. It is the leading NoSQL database. While Golang is a statically typed, compiled programming language designed at Google. It is built to be simple, high-performing, readable, and efficient.

CRUD operations with mongodb golang driver covers how to manage and perform various API - CRUD operations on a mongodb database using the mongodb golang driver. This will include: creating, reading, updating, and deleting documents from a mongo database.

This tutorial is a pratical one, which means we'll be learning by bulding a project. We'll be building the backend of a 'Photo Gallary App' that allow users to save their photos, delete photos, view photos at will, and am sure you get the point.

Prerequisites

To follow this tutorial, you will need:

  • Golang installed on you system, which you can get install from the Go offical website
  • Mongodb Database Connection URL, which you can easily generate by following this blog, Create A Mongodb Cluster and Generate A Connection String URL
  • Familiarity with the concept of a Data Base
  • Basic knowlege of Golang programming.

Install External Packages

In this section we will be installing all the external packages needed to build this project. We'll do this by executing a series of termitnal commands.

Create a new directory for this project and create a main.go file inside it.

  1. Initialising our project into a 'module'

    2. Before we start installing the packages we need for this project, open a terminal window pointing to you project directory and execute the following command:

    terminal
    > go mod init "gallary-app"

    This should create a new go.mod file in your project directory

  2. Install golang's gorilla/mux package

    3. Gorilla/mux is a popular external go package, used to create HTTP routers for go applications.

    Run the following terminal command in your project directory to install Gorilla/mux:

    terminal
    > go get -u github.com/gorilla/mux
  3. Install the mongodb golang driver

    4. Now let install the most important external package we will be needing for this application.

    Run the following terminal command in your project directory to install Go's mongodb driver:

    terminal
    > go get go.mongodb.org/mongo-driver/mongo

Create Router Using Gorilla/mux

Head to the main.go file and start by creating a router for this project using the Gorilla/mux package we installed earlier. Our router will be handling the following HTTP request:

Route Request Method Handler Function
"/get-photos" GET GetAllPhotos
"/get-photo/{id}" GET GetPhoto
"/create-photo" POST CreatePhoto
"/delete-photo/{id}" DELETE DeletePhoto
"/delete-photos" DELETE DeleteAllPhoto

First import the gorilla/mux package, then create a new router using the mux.NewRouter() function. Finally, create 5 router.HandleFunc() function to handle each request.

This is what your main.go file should look like:

main.go
                        package main
  
import (
  "github.com/gorilla/mux"
)

func main() {

    router := mux.NewRouter()
        
    router.HandleFunc("/get-photos", GetAllPhotos).Methods("GET")
    router.HandleFunc("/get-photo/{id}", GetPhoto).Methods("GET")
    router.HandleFunc("/create-photo", CreatePhoto).Methods("POST")
    router.HandleFunc("/update-photo/{id}", UpdatePhoto).Methods("PUT")
    router.HandleFunc("/delete-photo/{id}", DeletePhoto).Methods("DELETE")
    router.HandleFunc("/delete-photos", DeleteAllPhoto).Methods("DELETE")

}

Start Listening for HTTP Server Request

Next, start listening for server request on port 8080 using the http.ListenAndServe() function from the "net/http" package in the Go standard library. The function take two arguments: port number and http handler function, and it returns one value of type error, which we'll use to check for any errors.

main.go
                      ...
  
fmt.Println("starting server on port 8080")
serverErr := http.ListenAndServe(":8080", router)
if serverErr != nil {
    panic(serverErr)
}

Make sure you import the "net/http" package.

Connect To Mongodb

To connect to Mongodb, you need to create a Connection String URL using this format below and store in a variable.

txt
                              mongodb+srv://[username]:[password]@[cluster_name].wvunv.mongodb.net/[database]?retryWrites=true&w=majority

You can also generate a connect string URL by following this article, Create A Mongodb Cluster and Generate A Connection String URL.

Next, create context using the context.WithTimeout() function from the Go standard library.

Context is a standard package of Golang that makes it easy to pass request-scoped values, cancelation signals, and deadlines across API boundaries to all the goroutines involved in handling a request.

ref: educative.io

Parses your connection url using the options.Client().ApplyURI() function from the "mongo-driver/mongo/options" package we installed earlier.

Establish connection to the Mongodb using the mongo.connect() function.

At this point your main.go file should look like this:

main.go
                                package main
            
import (
    "context"
    "fmt"
    "time"
    "net/http"

    "github.com/gorilla/mux"
    "go.mongodb.org/mongo-driver/mongo"
    "go.mongodb.org/mongo-driver/mongo/options"
)

var Client *mongo.Client

func main() {

  router := mux.NewRouter()

  connectionURL := "mongodb+srv://daniel:my-secret-password@Tutorial-cluster.wvunv.mongodb.net/gallary-app?retryWrites=true&w=majority"

  ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(context.Background(), 10*time.Second)
  defer cancel()

  clientOption := options.Client().ApplyURI(connectionURL)

  mongoClient, connectionError := mongo.Connect(ctx, clientOption)
  if connectionError != nil {

      panic(connectionError)

  } else {
      Client = mongoClient

      // Start Listening for Server Request
      fmt.Println("starting server on port 8080")
      errSever := http.ListenAndServe(":8080", router)
      if errSever != nil {
          panic(errSever)
      }
  }

  
  // Routes
  router.HandleFunc("/get-photos", GetAllPhotos).Methods("GET")
  router.HandleFunc("/get-photo/{id}", GetPhoto).Methods("GET")
  router.HandleFunc("/create-photo", CreatePhoto).Methods("POST")
  router.HandleFunc("/update-photo/{id}", UpdatePhoto).Methods("PUT")
  router.HandleFunc("/delete-photo/{id}", DeletePhoto).Methods("DELETE")
  router.HandleFunc("/delete-photos", DeleteAllPhoto).Methods("DELETE")

}

The mongo.connect() function returns two values: mongoClient and connectionError. First we check for any connection error using the connectionError variable before proceeding.

mongoClient is our connection client to mongodb, we'll use this client to communicate to our mongodb, its why we store it in a globally decleared variable (Client) to make it accessible through out the application,

Notice we check for connection error before starting our server, now our server will only start running when we've connnected to mongodb.

Handle a POST Request to Mongodb

Lets start by creating a function (CreatePhoto()) to handle posting a new photo to our database.

Before creating the POST function, define a new struct that will represent the model or schema for each Photo object we post to our mongo database.

On line 12, I've created a new struct called Photo. We'll use the struct to make post request to mongodb.

main.go
                          import (
  "context"
  "fmt"
  "net/http"
  "time"

  "github.com/gorilla/mux"
  "go.mongodb.org/mongo-driver/mongo"
  "go.mongodb.org/mongo-driver/mongo/options"
)

type Photo struct {
  PhotoNumber int       `json:"photo_number"`
  Name        string    `json:"name"`
  Image       byte      `json:"photo"`
  Date        time.Time `json:"date"`
}
      
      ...

Now lets create a new handler function CreatePhoto. Below is the function that POST a new Photo to mongodb:

main.go
                          // Below we have our DATABASE QUERY FUNCTIONS
func CreatePhoto(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
  w.Header().Set("content-type", "application/json")

  var newPhoto Photo
  json.NewDecoder(r.Body).Decode(&newPhoto)

  collection := Client.Database("my-database").Collection("my-collection")

  ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(context.Background(), 10*time.Second)
  defer cancel()

  result, err := collection.InsertOne(ctx, newPhoto)
  if err != nil {
    panic(err)
  } else {
    json.NewEncoder(w).Encode(result)
  }
}

In our CreatePhoto function we start by setting our response "content-type" to json. Next we create a new variable of type Photo and decode the request body into it. On line 8, using your mongo client ( Client ) connect to the particular Database and Collection you want to store the item. Next create context.

Lastly, on line 13 we insert the item to mongodb by calling the InsertOne function on the mongo collection. the mongo.InsertOne function takes our context and Photo object as its arguments and returns an insertion result and insertion error. First we check for any error, in absence of any error we encode the result back to the front end.

Handle a Get-All Request from Mongodb

Below is handler function that gets all the items from our database.

main.go
                    // Below we have our DATABASE QUERY FUNCTIONS
...

func GetAllPhotos(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
  w.Header().Set("content-type", "application/json")

  collection := Client.Database("my-database").Collection("my-collection")

  ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(context.Background(), 10*time.Second)
  defer cancel()

  cursor, err := collection.Find(ctx, bson.M{})
  if err != nil {
    panic(err)
  } else {
    var allItems []bson.M
    if err = cursor.All(ctx, &allItems); err != nil {
      panic(err)
    } else {
      json.NewEncoder(w).Encode(allItems)
    }
  }
}

Be sure to import the "go.mongodb.org/mongo-driver/bson" from the mongo-driver we installed eailer

First we set our response content-type to json. Next we connect to the database collection we want to get our items from. Then create context for the get all quary.

On line 12 we call the Find function on our mongo collection. The function takes in context and a filter as its arguments, in this case we've used the BSON type bson.M{}, this get us an unordered representation of a BSON doucment. Read more about the mongodb BSON Data Types if you have a specific order you want to get your item, for example you might want to get only Photos from a particular date.

BSON is a binary encoded Javascript Object Notation (JSON)a textual object notation widely used to transmit and store data across web based applications. JSON is easier to understand as it is human-readable, but compared to BSON, it supports fewer data types. BSON encodes type and length information, too, making it easier for machines to parse.

The Find function returns a mongo Cursor. Note that the cursor is not our document, it is only a pointer to our document. On line 17 we access the data from the cursor by calling the All function on it, which iterates the cursor and decodes each document into the allItems slice.

In MongoDB, when the find() method is used to find the documents present in the given collection, then this method returned a pointer which will points to the documents of the collection, now this pointer is known as cursor. Or in other words we can say that a cursor is a pointer, and using this pointer we can access the document.

ref: geeksforgeeks.org

Handle Get-One Request from Mongodb

Below is the GetPhoto function that will get one item from our Collection using its uniqe PhotoNumber property in our Photo struct.

main.go

  ...
  
func GetPhoto(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
  w.Header().Set("content-type", "application/json")

  // Get the id parameter
  params := mux.Vars(r)
  id, _ := strconv.Atoi(params["id"])

  collection := Client.Database("my-database").Collection("my-collection")
  
  ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(context.Background(), 10*time.Second)
  defer cancel()

  err := collection.FindOne(ctx, Photo{PhotoNumber: id}).Decode(&photo)
  if err != nil {
    panic(err)
  } else {
    json.NewEncoder(w).Encode(photo)
  }
}

Set your content type to json, then get the id param from the url, then connect to your collection and create context.

Next, call the FindOne function on your mongo collection to get one item from your collection. The function take context and a filter as its arguments. In this case use the PhotoNumber property as the filter. Decode the result of this function into a Photo variable.

Handle DeleteOne Request to Mongodb

To delete an item from your collection, call the DeleteOne function on you mongo collection. The function takes context and a filter as arguments. Like we did earlier use the PhotoNumber property as the filter.

Below is the DeletePhoto function that will delete one item from our Collection using its uniqe PhotoNumber property in our Photo struct.

Handle DeleteAll Request to Mongodb

Let handle a request that empties our collection. To do this, call the DeleteMany function on your mongo collection. The function takes context and a filter as arguments. For the filter use the BSON type D. Since we're delete every item in the collection, we don't need to add any key to the filter.

Below is the DeleteAllPhoto function that will delete all the items from our collection

    json.NewEncoder(w).Encode(result)

Handle Update Request to Mongodb

If you'd like to add an update feature to your project, I'll show you how to do so in this section. You can update an item in your collection by calling the UpdateOne function on your mongo collection. The UpdateOne function take three arguments: context, a filter of the item you want to update, as well as what should be updated within the item.

The following code is an example of how to update an item in mongodb

func UpdatePhoto(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
  w.Header().Set("content-type", "application/json")

Introduction

The TCP/IP network model is referred to as a network suite. It is referred to as a suite because it consists of different networking protocols working together to transmit data packets from host A to host B and ensure a reliable connection between networks. These protocols are arranged in a hierarchy or stack, where the higher-level protocols make use of the protocols beneath them. TCP/IP is the backbone protocol on which the Internet runs and a core protocol for computer networking in general.

Several competing protocol suites exist, but TCP/IP has been by far the most successful over the decades. This is because of its elegant and flexible design and the fact that it is a nonproprietary protocol suite (not owned or controlled exclusively by a single entity).

In this article, we will break down the TCP/IP Network Model in more detail, define some key terms, and take a look at the TCP/IP layering model.

Definition of Terms

TCP - Transmission Control Protocol

TCP is a connection-oriented protocol that provides reliable data transfer, error detection and correction, segmentation, and reassembly. It operates at the Transport Layer of the TCP/IP Network Model and is a core protocol in the Internet protocol suite. TCP is often compared to UDP (User Diagram Data), but TCP is generally preferred in networks requiring high reliability due to its robust error-handling mechanisms.

IP - Internet Protocol

You've definitely heard the term "IP address" before. The Internet Protocol is a core protocol for transmitting data packets because it handles the tasks of addressing and routing packets. Every host must have an IP address through which packets can be addressed to it and every device with an IP address is considered a host. There are currently two standard versions of the Internet Protocol: IPv4 and IPv6. (Read more about IP here)

Packets

The term "packets" is used in various places in this article. It simply refers to small units of data. When transmitting data, large data sets are broken down into packets to meet the Maximum Transfer Unit (MTU) of a particular network. Each packet is framed with a header, which consists of its addressing information such as its source IP address and destination IP address.

A Practical Look at the TCP/IP Networking Model

In this section we'll take a shallow look at an instance of a Computer Network in action to better understand the role of the TCP/IP network model.

Assuming you have two laptops and need to transfer some files from Laptop A to Laptop B, you'll be presented with a couple of options (both wired and wireless). Let's assume you choose an Ethernet cable for the transfer. Modern systems have streamlined the data transfer process, making much of it opaque to the user. In this chapter, we'll delve deeper into the process of your files traveling from Laptop A to Laptop B.

After plugging each end of the Ethernet cable into both laptops, the next step is to assign each laptop an IP address within the same network range. For example, Laptop A could be assigned 10.10.10.1, while Laptop B would be assigned 10.10.10.2. This creates a private IP address range through which both laptops can transfer data addressed to each other's IP addresses. Each laptop automatically learns the other's IP address via an ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) request, and a connection is then established.

When you transfer files from Laptop A, addressed to Laptop B's IP address, the data passes through a series of TCP network layers to reach its destination. Let's delve into these layers and see their role in data transmission.

The TCP/IP Network Layers

The TCP/IP network model conventionally consists of four(4) distinct network layers: Application layer, Transport layer, Network layer, andLink layer. It's a simplified version of the original OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) network model, which consists of seven(7) layers: Application layer, Presentation layer, Session layer, Transport layer, Network layer, Data link layer, and Physical layer. The TCP/IP layer model combines some layers from the OSI model for simplification. Let's explore the four layers of the TCP/IP Network Model:

1. Link Layer

This layer is also known as the Network Interface Layer or Network Access Layer. It's responsible for framing and transmitting data bits over a physical medium. This can be transmitted wirelessly via electromagnetic waves or physically via wired signals. Examples of physical components include cables, optical fibers, radio waves, etc. In our practical example from the previous section < Practical Look at the TCP/IP Networking Model >, this would be the Ethernet cable used to connect the two computers.

Framing and Transmission is handle by two separate components of the Link layer:

  • Link Layer Control - Handles framing the packets
  • Media Access Control - Handles transmitting the packet to physical components.
2. Network or Internet Layer

This layer consists of protocols responsible for the logical transmission of data over a network. Examples of these protocols include: Internet Protocol (IP), Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP), and Address Resolution Protocol (ARP). Each of these protocols plays a specific role in transmitting data.

In our practical example from the previous section < Practical Look at the TCP/IP Networking Model >, we assigned different but similar IP addresses to each laptop. The similarity (10.10.10.x) indicates that they belong to the same subnet. As Laptop A transmits a data packet to Laptop B, the packet will be framed in Laptop A's Link Layer Control. The frame will contain Laptop B's IP address as the destination.

If there were more than two laptops connected to the network, communication would be impossible without IP addresses. IP addresses are essential for each laptop to know how to send files to others within the network.

3. Transport Layer

This layer consists of protocols that provide reliable data transfer from one host in a network to the endpoint or receiving host of the network. It is concerned with end-to-end communication. TCP, UDP, and SCTP (Stream Control Transmission Protocol) are examples of Transport layer protocols.

End-to-end communication means sender-to-receiver communication. In our practical example from the previous section < Practical Look at the TCP/IP Networking Model >, we looked at a very simple network topology involving only two devices. In the Internet or a more complex network topology, data does not always travel directly from one host to another. It usually hops through a series of routes before reaching its destination host.

Communication between one route and the next route is referred to as hop-to-hop communication while the overall communication between the source host and destination host is the end-to-end communication.

As packets travel through these complex topologies, they are always aware of their next hop through a Layer 2 header using a MAC (Media Access Control) address and their destination host through a Layer 3 header using an IP address. Every IOT device is assigned a unique MAC address at the time of manufacture.

4. Application Layer

This layer combines the Session and Presentation layers from the OSI layer model. The Application layer consists of protocols that work directly with the end user's applications, providing various network services to these applications. Some Application layer protocols include SSH (Secure Shell), FTP (File Transfer Protocol), HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol), DNS (Domain Name System), SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol), and many more.

Conclusion

In this exploration of the TCP/IP Network Model, we've delved into the fundamental layers and protocols that underpin modern computer networking.

We've examined how data flows through the network, starting at the Application layer and traversing the Transport, Network, and Link layers. We've also explored the roles of key protocols like TCP, IP, and ARP in ensuring reliable and efficient communication.

By understanding the TCP/IP model, you gain a deeper appreciation for the complex processes involved in modern computer networking. This knowledge can be valuable for troubleshooting network issues, designing network architectures, and staying informed about emerging networking technologies.
